pli-tv-kd3:0.3: The chapter on entering the rainy-season residence
pli-tv-kd3:0.4: The instruction to enter the rainy-season residence
pli-tv-kd3:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-kd3:1.1.2: At that time the Buddha had not yet laid down the rainy-season residence for the monks.
pli-tv-kd3:1.1.3: And so the monks were wandering about in the winter, in the summer, and also during the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd3:1.2.2: “How can the Sakyan ascetics go wandering in the winter, in the summer, and even during the rainy season? They are trampling down the green grass, oppressing life with one sense faculty, and destroying many small creatures.
pli-tv-kd3:1.2.3: Even the ascetics of other religions, with their flawed teachings, settle down for the rainy-season.
pli-tv-kd3:1.2.4: Even birds make a nest in the top of a tree and settle down for the rainy-season.
pli-tv-kd3:1.2.5: But not so the Sakyan ascetics.”
pli-tv-kd3:1.3.1: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-kd3:1.3.3: Soon afterwards he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd3:2.1.2: “When should we enter the rains residence?”
pli-tv-kd3:2.1.3: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd3:2.1.4: “You should enter the rainy-season residence during the rainy season.”
pli-tv-kd3:2.2.2: “How many entries to the rains residence are there?”
pli-tv-kd3:2.2.4: “There are two entries to the rainy-season residence:
pli-tv-kd3:2.2.6: You should enter the first on the day after the full moon of July and the second one month after the full moon of July.”
pli-tv-kd3:3.1.0: The prohibition against wandering during the rainy season, etc.
pli-tv-kd3:3.1.1: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six entered the rains residence and then went wandering during the rainy season.
pli-tv-kd3:3.2.1: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-kd3:3.2.2: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd3:3.2.3: “How can the monks from the group of six enter the rains residence and then go wandering during the rainy season?”
pli-tv-kd3:3.2.5: Soon afterwards he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd3:3.2.6: “After entering the rainy-season residence, you should stay put for the first or the second three-month period before you go wandering.
pli-tv-kd3:3.2.7: If you go wandering during the rainy-season residence period, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd3:4.1.1: The monks from the group of six did not want to enter the rains residence.
pli-tv-kd3:4.1.4: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd3:4.2.1: On the day of the entry to the rains residence, the monks from the group of six deliberately bypassed a monastery because they did not want to enter the rains residence.
pli-tv-kd3:4.2.3: “On the day of the entry to the rainy-season residence, you should not deliberately bypass a monastery because you don’t want to enter the rainy-season residence.
pli-tv-kd3:4.2.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd3:4.3.1: At one time King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha wanted to postpone the rains residence. He sent a message to the monks:
pli-tv-kd3:4.3.2: “Would the venerables please enter the rains residence the next full moon?”
pli-tv-kd3:4.3.4: “You should comply with the wishes of kings.”

pli-tv-kd3:6.1.0: The allowance to go to five kinds of people even if not sent for
pli-tv-kd3:6.1.1: On one occasion a certain monk was sick.
pli-tv-kd3:6.1.2: He sent a message to the monks:
pli-tv-kd3:6.1.4: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd3:6.1.5: “Even if you’re not sent for, let alone if you are, I allow you to go for seven days to five kinds of people—
pli-tv-kd3:6.1.6: a monk, a nun, a trainee nun, a novice monk, or a novice nun.
pli-tv-kd3:6.1.8: But you should return within seven days.”

pli-tv-kd3:7.1.0: The allowance to go to seven kinds of people even if not sent for
pli-tv-kd3:7.1.1: On one occasion the mother of a certain monk was sick.
pli-tv-kd3:7.1.2: She sent a message to her son:
pli-tv-kd3:7.1.5: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd3:7.1.6: that one should go for seven days to seven kinds of people, but only when sent for,
pli-tv-kd3:7.1.7: and that one should go for seven days to five kinds of people, even if not sent for, let alone if one is.
pli-tv-kd3:7.1.8: My mother is sick, but she’s not a lay follower. So what should I do?”
pli-tv-kd3:7.1.9: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd3:7.2.1: “Even if you’re not sent for, let alone if you are, I allow you to go for seven days to seven kinds of people—
pli-tv-kd3:7.2.2: a monk, a nun, a trainee nun, a novice monk, a novice nun, your mother, your father.
pli-tv-kd3:7.2.4: But you should return within seven days.

pli-tv-kd3:7.3.4: ʻI’ll look for food for my sick mother and for the nurses; I’ll look for medicine; and I’ll enquire about her sickness and nurse her.’
pli-tv-kd3:7.3.5: But you should return within seven days.

pli-tv-kd3:8.1.1: At one time when one of the Sangha’s dwellings was falling apart,
pli-tv-kd3:8.1.2: the timber belonging to a certain lay follower had been cut up in the wilderness.
pli-tv-kd3:8.1.3: He sent a message to the monks:

pli-tv-kd3:9.1.0: The section on no offense for breaking the rains residence if there are dangers
pli-tv-kd3:9.1.1: At one time in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country, monks who had entered the rains residence were harassed by predatory animals
pli-tv-kd3:9.1.3: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd3:9.1.4: “It may happen that monks who have entered the rains residence are harassed by predatory animals
pli-tv-kd3:9.1.6: When there is such a danger, you should leave.
pli-tv-kd3:9.1.7: There is no offense for breaking the rains residence.
pli-tv-kd3:9.1.8: It may happen that monks who have entered the rains residence are harassed by creeping animals
pli-tv-kd3:9.1.10: When there is such a danger, you should leave.
pli-tv-kd3:9.1.11: There is no offense for breaking the rains residence.
pli-tv-kd3:9.2.1: It may happen that monks who have entered the rains residence are harassed by criminals
pli-tv-kd3:9.2.2: who steal from them and beat them up.
pli-tv-kd3:9.2.3: When there is such a danger, you should leave.
pli-tv-kd3:9.2.4: There is no offense for breaking the rains residence.
pli-tv-kd3:9.2.5: It may happen that monks who have entered the rains residence are harassed by demons

pli-tv-kd3:9.2.7: When there is such a danger, you should leave.
pli-tv-kd3:9.2.8: There is no offense for breaking the rains residence.”
pli-tv-kd3:9.3.1: “It may happen that the village where the monks have entered the rains residence burns.

pli-tv-kd3:13.1.2: that they would not give the going forth during the rains residence.

pli-tv-kd3:14.1.0: Offense of wrong conduct for assenting
pli-tv-kd3:14.1.1: On one occasion Venerable Upananda the Sakyan had assented to spend the first rains residence at the invitation of King Pasenadi of Kosala.
pli-tv-kd3:14.1.2: As he was walking to the monastery provided by the King, he saw two monasteries with much robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd3:14.1.4: “Perhaps I should spend the rains residence in these two monasteries?
pli-tv-kd3:14.1.5: In that way I’ll get much robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-kd3:14.1.6: And he spent the rains residence in those two monasteries.
pli-tv-kd3:14.1.7: King Pasenadi complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-kd3:14.1.8: “How could Upananda agree to spend the rains residence in my monastery, but then break his word?
pli-tv-kd3:14.1.9: Hasn’t the Buddha in many ways criticized lying and praised the abstention from lying?”
pli-tv-kd3:14.2.1: The monks heard the King’s complaints,
pli-tv-kd3:14.2.2: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,
pli-tv-kd3:14.3.2: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
pli-tv-kd3:14.3.3: “Is it true that you acted like this?”
pli-tv-kd3:14.3.6: “… Foolish man, how can you agree to spend the rains residence at the invitation of King Pasenadi, but then break your word?
pli-tv-kd3:14.3.7: Haven’t I criticized lying in many ways and praised the abstention from lying?
pli-tv-kd3:14.3.8: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
